   17311           0 :   determine_get_call_for_tuple_like_binding(container, tp, elem_idx, diag_pos,
   17312             :                                             p_icp, &lvalue_binding);
   17313             :   /* Add a reference on top of e_type, applying the reference-collapsing
   17314             :      rules if needed.  An lvalue reference is added if lvalue_binding is
   17315             :      TRUE, an rvalue reference otherwise. */
   17316           0 :   if (is_reference_type(e_type)) {
   17317           0 :     e_type = make_reference_to_reference(e_type,
   17318             :                                          /*rvalue_ref=*/!lvalue_binding,
   17319             :                                          /*tracking_ref=*/FALSE,
   17320             :                                          TQ_NONE, diag_pos, (a_boolean*)NULL);

   17329             : 
   17330           0 : static a_field_ptr next_bindable_field(a_field_ptr field)
   17331             : /*
   17332             : Given a pointer to a field (or NULL), return a pointer to the first field at
   17333             : or after the given field that a structured binding can bind to.  If there is
   17334             : no next such field, return NULL.  This is similar to next_initializable_field,
   17335             : but it skips fields generated by lowering (e.g., a virtual function table
   17336             : pointer) and does not skip anonymous union parent objects.
   17337             : */
   17338             : {
   17339           0 :   for (; field != NULL; field = field->next) {
   17340             :     /* Skip fields generated by lowering. */
   17341           0 :     if (symbol_for(field) == NULL) continue;
   17342             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   17343             :     /* Skip any property or event fields. */
   17344             :     if (field->property_or_event_descr != NULL) continue;
   17345             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   17346             :     /* Unnamed bit fields are not bindable. */
   17347           0 :     if (has_name(field) || !field->is_bit_field) break;
   17348             :   }  /* for */
   17349           0 :   return field;
   17350             : }  /* next_bindable_field */
   17351             : 
   17352             : 
   17353           0 : static a_field_ptr get_direct_fields_if_nonempty(a_type_ptr  tp)

   17359           0 :   a_field_ptr  result = tp->variant.class_struct_union.field_list, fp;

   17365             : 
   17366           0 : static a_boolean check_simple_struct_for_binding(
   17367             :                                                a_type_ptr         tp,
   17368             :                                                a_targ_size_t      *n_elements,
   17369             :                                                a_field_ptr        *p_fields,
   17370             :                                                a_source_position  *pos)
   17371             : /*
   17372             : Return TRUE if the given type is a simple class type whose nonstatic data
   17373             : members are all direct members or all members of the same unambiguous base
   17374             : class.  If so, set *n_elements to the number of such data members and
   17375             : *p_fields to the list of fields to bind to (this list may include unnamed bit
   17376             : fields that should not be bound to).  Otherwise, issue a diagnostic at the
   17377             : given position.
   17378             : */
   17379             : {
   17380           0 :   a_boolean    result = TRUE;
   17381           0 :   a_field_ptr  fields = NULL;
   17382             : 
   17383           0 :   tp = skip_typerefs(tp);
   17384           0 :   if (tp->kind != (a_type_kind)tk_struct &&
   17385             :       tp->kind != (a_type_kind)tk_class) {
   17386           0 :     pos_ty_error(ec_invalid_struct_binding_type, pos, tp);
   17387           0 :     result = FALSE;
   17388           0 :   } else if (class_type_supp(tp)->is_lambda_closure_class) {
   17389           0 :     pos_error(ec_struct_binding_lambda, pos);
   17390           0 :     result = FALSE;
   17391             :   } else {
   17392           0 :     a_base_class_ptr  bcp = base_classes_of(tp);
   17393             :     /* Set fields to the direct data members of tp first. */
   17394           0 :     fields = get_direct_fields_if_nonempty(tp);
   17395           0 :     fields = next_bindable_field(fields);
   17396             :     /* Now explore the base classes for similar members and issue an error
   17397             :        if we find some in multiple places. */
   17398           0 :     for (; bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {
   17399           0 :       a_field_ptr  base_fields = get_direct_fields_if_nonempty(bcp->type);
   17400           0 :       if (base_fields != NULL) {
   17401           0 :         if (fields != NULL) {
   17402           0 :           pos_ty_error(ec_invalid_struct_binding_type, pos, tp);
   17403           0 :           result = FALSE;
   17404           0 :           break;
   17405             :         } else {
   17406             :           fields = base_fields;
   17407             :         }  /* if */
   17408             :       }  /* if */
   17409             :     }  /* for */
   17410           0 :     if (result) {
   17411             :       /* No errors: Count the number of members we will bind to. */
   17412           0 :       a_field_ptr    fp = next_bindable_field(fields);
   17413             :       a_targ_size_t  n = 0;
   17414           0 :       while (fp != NULL) {

   17418           0 :           pos_ty_error(ec_invalid_struct_binding_type, pos, tp);

   17423             :       }  /* while */

   17426           0 :         *p_fields = fields;

   17429             :   }  /* if */
   17430           0 :   return result;
   17431             : }  /* check_simple_struct_for_binding */

   17523           0 : void define_struct_bindings(a_decl_parse_state  *dps)
   17524             : /*
   17525             : dps represents a structured binding declaration (and the container variable,
   17526             : which has just been declared, in particular).  Define the variables
   17527             : representing the individual bindings.  They were declared earlier by a call to
   17528             : declare_struct_bindings (as "auto" variable); now their type and initializer
   17529             : can be fully determined.
   17530             : */

   17532           0 :   a_boolean       err = FALSE, tuple_case = FALSE, array_case = FALSE;

   17579           0 :     } else if (n == n_elements) {

   17624           0 :     vp->type = btype;
   17625           0 :     vp->declared_with_auto_type_specifier = FALSE;
   17626             :     /* Record an initializer for the binding variable (if applicable). */
   17627           0 :     if (err || dependent_case) {
   17628             :       /* No initializer to record. */

   17687        8025 : static void variable_declaration(a_decl_parse_state  *state,
   17688             :                                  a_symbol_locator    *locator,
   17689             :                                  a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block)
   17690             : /*
   17691             : Process a variable declaration not directly appearing in a class scope (i.e.,
   17692             : ordinary namespace scope declarations, block-extern declarations, and out-of-
   17693             : class definitions of static data members).  The declaration is described by

   18294             : static an_end_of_decl_action

   18758     1184110 : static an_end_of_decl_action prep_for_declarator(
   18759             :                                     a_decl_parse_state  *state,
   18760             :                                     a_decl_flag_set     *p_di_flags)
   18761             : /*
   18762             : A helper routine for "scan_nonmember_declaration" (see below) that determines
   18763             : whether to scan declarators.  If they are to be scanned, set up the initial
   18764             : value for the input flags (pointed to by p_di_flags) in the call to
   18765             : "declarator".  state describes the declaration being processed.  This function
   18766             : is called from "scan_nonmember_declaration" and its return value indicates how
   18767             : processing should proceed after the call.
   18768             : */
   18769             : {
   18770     1184110 :   an_end_of_decl_action   end_of_decl_action = eoda_not_at_end;
   18771     1184110 :   a_decl_flag_set         dso_flags = state->dso_flags;
   18772     1184110 :   a_decl_flag_set         di_flags = DI_NO_INPUT_FLAGS;
   18773     1184110 :   a_boolean               declarator_omitted = FALSE;
   18774             : 
   18775     1184110 :   if (dso_flags & DSO_LINKAGE_SPEC_DECL) {
   18776             :     /* A linkage-specifier will be found among the decl_specifiers only in
   18777             :        Microsoft mode -- e.g., for a case like this:
   18778             :          extern "C" __declspec(dllexport) void f();
   18779             :        Moreover, it is allowed only if this is not already a linkage-specifier
   18780             :        declaration -- i.e., an error should have been issued on
   18781             :          extern "C" __declspec(dllexport) extern "C" void f();
   18782             :     */
   18783           0 :     check_assertion(microsoft_mode && !state->is_linkage_spec_decl);
   18784             :     /* Set a flag to treat this as a normal linkage-specification
   18785             :        declaration. */
   18786             :     state->is_linkage_spec_decl = TRUE;
   18787             :     /* push_name_linkage was called in decl_specifiers, and the corresponding
   18788             :        pop must be done before exiting this routine. */
   18789             :     state->restore_name_linkage = TRUE;
   18790     1184110 :   } else if (state->is_linkage_spec_decl) {
   18791             :     /* Record the fact that this declaration has a linkage specifier attached
   18792             :        directly to it (as opposed to just being inside a linkage block). */
   18793         117 :     state->decl_modifiers.direct_linkage_specifier = TRUE;
   18794             :   }  /* if */
   18795     1184110 :   if (!state->decl_specifiers_omitted) {
   18796             :     /* Check for cases without a declarator and issue a diagnostic if it's
   18797             :        invalid. */
   18798     1184100 :     declarator_omitted = check_for_missing_declarator(state);

   19001      862792 : void check_use_of_placeholder_type(a_decl_parse_state  *dps)

   19133           0 : static a_boolean is_terse_range_based_for_declaration(void)

   19144           0 :     a_token_cache            cache;

   19146           0 :     begin_caching_fetched_tokens(/*include_curr_token=*/TRUE);
   19147           0 :     (void)get_token();

   19149             :       /* Skip attributes. */
   19150           0 :       flush_until_matching_token_full(/*limit_flush=*/FALSE);
   19151           0 :       (void)get_token();

   19153           0 :     result = curr_token == tok_colon;
   19154           0 :     end_caching_fetched_tokens();

   19156             :     /* Get the tokens that were fetched by this routine from the cache
   19157             :        that has been accumulated and rescan them. */
   19158           0 :     copy_tokens_from_cache(curr_lexical_state_cache(), start_tsn,
   19159             :                            last_token_sequence_number_of_token,

   19166             : 
   19167             : 
   19168     1202120 : void scan_nonmember_declaration(a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
   19169             :                                 a_source_range      *linkage_spec_range_ptr)
   19170             : /*
   19171             : This routine scans declarations in the following scope kinds: file scope,
   19172             : namespace scope, function scope, condition scope, and block scope.  It is also
   19173             : used to scan old-style C parameter declarations (in which case
   19174             : dps->is_old_style_param_decl is TRUE and dps->param_id_list will list the
   19175             : parameter names in the associated function declarator).
   19176             : 
   19177             : *dps tracks the properties of the declaration being parsed.  The caller can
   19178             : set some of its fields to guide processing (e.g., dps->is_old_style_param_decl
   19179             : should be set to TRUE and dps->param_id_list should list the parameter names in
   19180             : the associated function declarator to scan old-style parameter definitions),
   19181             : while other fields will be set so the caller can inspect the outcome of the
   19182             : declaration (e.g., dps->sym points to the principal symbol, if any, entered for
   19183             : the declaration).
   19184             : 
   19185             : linkage_spec_range_ptr is non-NULL when this declaration includes an explicit
   19186             : linkage specification, but is otherwise NULL, even when it is part of a block
   19187             : of declarations governed by a linkage specification (i.e., it is non-NULL for
   19188             : `extern "C" void f()' and NULL for `extern "C" { void f() }'); when it is
   19189             : non-NULL, it indicates the source range of the linkage specifier.
   19190             : 
   19191             : Broadly speaking, three kinds of declarations are handled here:
   19192             :   1. Declarations consisting of "declarators" optionally preceded by some
   19193             :      "specifiers".  This includes declarations of variables, functions, and
   19194             :      typedefs, as well as out-of-class definitions of member functions and
   19195             :      static data members.
   19196             :      A single declaration may sometimes introduce multiple comma-separated
   19197             :      declarators: This is handled by the main do-while loop containing a
   19198             :      call to "declarator"; the loop is preceded by a call to "decl_specifiers"
   19199             :      which scans the specifiers (if any).
   19200             :   2. Declarations that consist only of "specifiers".  (Normally, these are
   19201             :      declarations of class types or enumeration types, but various error cases
   19202             :      also follow this path.)
   19203             :   3. Declarations that do not fall in the previous two categories.  Examples
   19204             :      include namespace declarations, using-declarations, template declarations,
   19205             :      static_assert constructs, and so forth.  These cases are treated by the
   19206             :      call to "check_special_declaration_form".
   19207             : 
   19208             : Declarations in class scope are handled by the similar routine
   19209             : "class_member_declaration".  Ordinary (as opposed to old-style) function
   19210             : parameter declarations are scanned by function_declarator, and template
   19211             : parameters are scanned by scan_a_template_parameter_declaration.
   19212             : */
   19213             : {
   19214     1202120 :   a_decl_flag_set              dsi_flags, di_flags;
   19215     1202120 :   a_boolean                    is_function;
   19216     1202120 :   a_symbol_locator             locator;

   19565     1194310 : void declaration(a_boolean       function_definition_allowed,

   19571             : /*
   19572             : Wrapper function for scan_nonmember_declaration that sets up a declaration
   19573             : parse state with fields described by the corresponding given parameters.
   19574             : */

   19576     1194310 :   a_decl_parse_state  dps;

   19593             : 
   19594         320 : void translation_unit(void)
   19595             : /*
   19596             : Scan a translation-unit (3.7).  This is the topmost syntactic entity in
   19597             : a compilation.  The syntax is
   19598             : 
   19599             : 3.7    translation-unit:
   19600             :                 external-declaration
   19601             :                 translation-unit external-declaration
   19602             : 
   19603             : In C++, however, the declaration list is optional (3.4):
   19604             : 
   19605             :        translation-union:
   19606             :                 declaration-seq
   19607             :                                opt
   19608             : */
   19609             : {
   19610         320 :   if (using_a_pch_file) {
   19611             :     /* When using a precompiled header, do any special processing needed
   19612             :        for a preincluded file. */

   19616             :      macro definitions. */

   19619         320 :   next_token_is_top_level_decl_start = TRUE;
   19620         320 :   (void)get_token();

   19622         320 :   if (next_event_resumes_compilation) {

   19624             :         to skip over the part of the file that is being replaced by
   19625             :         information from the PCH).  We've encountered the first token of
   19626             :         the normal compilation.  Do any fixup required. */

   19631           0 :     if (C_mode()) {
   19632             :       /* A translation unit cannot be empty.  Note that this can happen not
   19633             :          only for an empty file, but also for a file containing only
   19634             :          preprocessing directives.  pcc allows an empty source file.
   19635             :          In ANSI mode, it's allowed as an extension. */

   19637           0 :         diagnostic(strict_ansi_error_severity, ec_empty_translation_unit);

   19691           0 : void scan_top_level_generated_code(a_const_char      *buffer,
   19692             :                                    an_assembly_index assembly_index,
   19693             :                                    a_boolean         is_metadata)
   19694             : /*
   19695             : Scan top level declarations of "generated code" given by *buffer.  Generated
   19696             : code can be code read from assembly files (i.e., metadata), or directly from
